Texas AI centers guzzle 463 million gallons, now residents are asked to cut back on showers10/20/2025

Texas AI data centers water usage: As Texas faces a severe drought, the state's AI data centers consume millions of gallons of water daily for cooling, raising concerns about environmental sustainability. Residents are urged to conserve water while these centers operate extensively, prompting a call to action regarding water usage policies.

Texas AI Data Centers, Data Center Water Usage, Water Conservation, Drought in Texas, Water CrisisRead

Microsoft's Stargate campus leads this surge, raising environmental concerns. Data centers in Central Texas used 463 million gallons in 2023-24 alone, enough for tens of thousands of homes.</p></div><article competitionClients="" currency_ad="1" data-apw="" class="artData clr "><div class="imgBox"><figure class="artImg"><img height="225" width="300" alt="Texas AI centers guzzle 463 million gallons, now residents are asked to cut back on showers" src="https://img.etimg.com/thumb/msid-122983416,width-300,height-225,imgsize-297268,resizemode-75/texas-ai-centers-guzzle-463-million-gallons-now-residents-are-asked-to-cut-back-on-showers.jpg"><span class="imgAgency">TIL Creatives</span></figure></div><div data-brCount="39" class="artText"><strong><a ref="dofollow" data-ga-onclick="Inarticle articleshow link click#News#href" href="/topic/texas-ai-data-centers-water-usage" target="_blank">Texas AI data centers water usage</a>: </strong>Amid the ongoing worsening drought condition in Texas, the State's residents face an unexpected water dilemma: while communities are urged to conserve every drop, even cutting back on simple showers, massive new AI data centers are quietly using millions of gallons daily to keep their operations running, as per a report.<br><br><style>

    	</style><!--/dynamic_link.cms?msid=107107653&subsecid=1715249553&pos=toppotime:1--><h2>Microsoft’s Stargate Campus Leads the AI Data Center Boom</h2>Microsoft’s Stargate campus in Abilene is leading a surge in data center construction, promising to become one of the world’s largest hubs supporting advanced artificial intelligence technology, as per a report by Techie + Gamers. <br><div data-mid-newpos-mgid="mgid_122983253" id="div-mgid-mid-newpos-122983253"></div><br><h2>Texas AI Data Centers Use Millions of Gallons of Water Amid Severe Drought</h2>But behind this high-tech promise lies a growing environmental concern: water consumption. According to a July 2025 investigation by The Austin Chronicle, data centers across Central Texas, including Microsoft and US Army Corps facilities in San Antonio, used a combined 463 million gallons of water in 2023 and 2024 alone, as reported by Techie + Gamers. That’s enough water to meet the needs of tens of thousands of households, according to the report.<div id="E_3" class="etoro" style="height:auto; width:650px; margin: 2px 0 10px;"></div><br><div class="adBox custom_ad nonm taboola" data-taboola="taboola_122983253"><iframe src="" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true" allowfullscreen="true" width="625" height="375" frameborder="0" class="gam_video" title="GAM video for article content"></iframe><div data-placement="Mid Article Thumbnails" data-target_type="mix" data-mode="thumbnails-mid" style="min-height:400px; margin-bottom:12px;" class="wdt-taboola" id="taboola-mid-article-thumbnails-122983253"></div></div><br>ALSO READ: <a data-ga-onclick="Inarticle articleshow link click#News#href" href="https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/us/prsm-missile-pentagons-new-missile-could-checkmate-china-why-everyones-talking-about-it-us-military-news/articleshow/122982803.cms?utm_source=contentofinterest&utm_medium=text&utm_campaign=cppst" data-type="tilCustomLink" target="_blank">Pentagon’s new missile could checkmate China — why everyone’s talking about it</a><br><br><h2>Why Data Centers Use So Much Water</h2>For many Texans, this feels like a painful contradiction. While drought warnings urge residents to limit water use, especially for everyday activities like showering, giant facilities essential to the tech economy are quietly drawing vast amounts of water, mostly for cooling servers that keep the data centers running 24/7, as per the Techie + Gamers report.<br><style>

    		</style><div style="display:none;" data-ga-impression="Events_widget_$pagename#Impression#url" class="liveEventMain_widget custom_ad"><div class="topContain"><div class="imgBox"><img alt="ET logo" src="https://img.etimg.com/photo/118783427.cms" width="90%"></div><h3 class="logoTitle">Live Events</h3><p class="logoSubTitle"></p></div><div class="liveEvent_slider"><ul class="sliderContainer"></ul></div><div class="nextprev-btn"><span class="arrow_btn prev-btn cSprite disable"></span><span class="arrow_btn next-btn cSprite"></span></div><div class="ts-dots"><ul class="sliderContainer"></ul></div></div><!--/live_events_widget.cms?pagename=articlepotime:2--><br><div data-mid-vdoai="vdoai_122983253" id="div-vdoai-mid-122983253"></div> Robert Mace, executive director of The Meadows Center for Water and the Environment at Texas State University highlighted that, “People don’t think of data centers as industrial water users, but they are,” adding that, “Once that water evaporates, it’s just gone,” as quoted in the report.<br><br><div data-size="[[300, 250], [600, 250], [600, 300]]" data-adsSlot="/7176/Economictimes/ET_News/ET_News_InternationalBusiness/ET_ROS_MID_NWS_IBZ_AS_300" data-loc="100" id="div-gpt-ad-858478126-122983253" class="country_specAD"></div>ALSO READ: <a data-ga-onclick="Inarticle articleshow link click#News#href" href="https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/us/gen-z-careers-google-and-meta-no-longer-cool-75-of-grads-are-walking-away-from-big-tech-dreams-for-new-career-paths/articleshow/122980830.cms?utm_source=contentofinterest&utm_medium=text&utm_campaign=cppst" data-type="tilCustomLink" target="_blank">Google and Meta no longer cool? 75% of grads are walking away from Big Tech dreams for new career paths</a><br><br><div data-size="[[300, 250], [600, 250], [600, 300]]" data-adsSlot="/7176/Economictimes/ET_News/ET_News_InternationalBusiness/ET_ROS_MID1_NWS_IBZ_AS_300" data-loc="2" id="div-gpt-ad-858478132-122983253" class="country_specAD2nd"></div><div data-size="[[300, 250], [600, 250], [600, 300]]" data-adsSlot="/7176/Economictimes/ET_News/ET_News_InternationalBusiness/ET_ROS_MID1_NWS_IBZ_AS_300" data-loc="5" id="div-gpt-ad-858478132-122983253" class="country_specAD2nd"></div><div data-size="[[300, 250], [600, 250], [600, 300]]" data-adsSlot="/7176/Economictimes/ET_News/ET_News_InternationalBusiness/ET_ROS_MID1_NWS_IBZ_AS_300" data-loc="3" id="div-gpt-ad-858478132-122983253" class="country_specAD2nd"></div><h2>Experts Stress the Industrial Scale of Data Center Water Use</h2>The scale of water use is massive, as the Texas Water Development Board projections estimate that data centers in the state will consume 49 billion gallons of water in 2025, soaring to nearly 400 billion gallons by 2030, as per Techie + Gamers report. That’s about 7% of Texas’s total projected water use, according to the report.<br><br>Margaret Cook, a water policy analyst at the Houston Advanced Research Center pointed out that, “These centers are showing up in places that are very water-stressed," adding, "There’s no requirement for them to have conversations with communities about how much water they’ll use,” as quoted in the report.<br><br>Locals in the Hill Country region, where several new AI-focused centers are under construction, are raising alarms. Much of the water these centers use evaporates during cooling and can’t be recycled, a critical issue in an area already grappling with scarce water resources, as reported by Techie + Gamers.<br><br>ALSO READ: <a data-ga-onclick="Inarticle articleshow link click#News#href" href="https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/us/wyoming-ai-data-center-power-consumption-giant-wyoming-data-center-to-guzzle-5x-more-power-than-residents-but-the-user-remains-secret-open-ai-latest-news/articleshow/123242782.cms?utm_source=contentofinterest&utm_medium=text&utm_campaign=cppst">Giant Wyoming data center to guzzle 5x more power than residents, but the user remains secret</a><br><br><h2>Microsoft’s Sustainability Promise Faces Skepticism</h2>While Microsoft said it’s working toward sustainability goals, aiming to be “water positive” by 2030, meaning it plans to replenish more water than it consumes, as per the report. The company highlights water restoration projects and the use of recycled water when possible, according to Techie + Gamers. <br><br>However, critics worry these efforts often happen far from the communities facing water shortages, limiting their impact.<br><br> Cook said, “You have to question what ‘water positive’ means when you’re building massive projects in places already dealing with water scarcity,” as quoted in the report.<br><br>Transparency is another problem. Some water utilities learn about new data centers only after construction is underway, and companies sometimes operate under shell entities or code names, reducing community awareness and input, as reported by Techie + Gamers.<br><br>This issue isn’t just about the future, it’s happening now, with drought conditions already severe across many parts of Texas, the expansion of AI infrastructure is testing how communities balance technological progress with environmental sustainability, as per Techie + Gamers.<br><br>ALSO READ: <a data-ga-onclick="Inarticle articleshow link click#News#href" href="https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/us/us-layoffs-latest-news-august-2025-layoffs-full-list-warn-notices-job-cuts-as-the-july-jobs-report-paints-a-grim-picture-114-companies-plan-layoffs-in-august-is-yours-on-list/articleshow/123047638.cms?utm_source=contentofinterest&utm_medium=text&utm_campaign=cppst">As the July jobs report paints a grim picture, 114 companies plan layoffs in August - is yours on the list?</a><br><br><h2>FAQs</h2><strong>Why are Texas AI data centers using so much water?</strong><br>They use water mainly to cool the servers that run around the clock, which is essential to keep the data centers operating safely.<br><strong><br>Can the water used by data centers be recycled?</strong><br>Some water is recycled, but a large portion evaporates during cooling and is lost forever.<br><style>

readabilityObject.title: Texas AI centers guzzle 463 million gallons, now residents are asked to cut back on showers
readabilityObject.content:
Texas AI data centers water usage: Amid the ongoing worsening drought condition in Texas, the State's residents face an unexpected water dilemma: while communities are urged to conserve every drop, even cutting back on simple showers, massive new AI data centers are quietly using millions of gallons daily to keep their operations running, as per a report.

Microsoft’s Stargate Campus Leads the AI Data Center Boom

Microsoft’s Stargate campus in Abilene is leading a surge in data center construction, promising to become one of the world’s largest hubs supporting advanced artificial intelligence technology, as per a report by Techie + Gamers.


Texas AI Data Centers Use Millions of Gallons of Water Amid Severe Drought

But behind this high-tech promise lies a growing environmental concern: water consumption. According to a July 2025 investigation by The Austin Chronicle, data centers across Central Texas, including Microsoft and US Army Corps facilities in San Antonio, used a combined 463 million gallons of water in 2023 and 2024 alone, as reported by Techie + Gamers. That’s enough water to meet the needs of tens of thousands of households, according to the report.


ALSO READ: Pentagon’s new missile could checkmate China — why everyone’s talking about it

Why Data Centers Use So Much Water

For many Texans, this feels like a painful contradiction. While drought warnings urge residents to limit water use, especially for everyday activities like showering, giant facilities essential to the tech economy are quietly drawing vast amounts of water, mostly for cooling servers that keep the data centers running 24/7, as per the Techie + Gamers report.

Robert Mace, executive director of The Meadows Center for Water and the Environment at Texas State University highlighted that, “People don’t think of data centers as industrial water users, but they are,” adding that, “Once that water evaporates, it’s just gone,” as quoted in the report.

ALSO READ: Google and Meta no longer cool? 75% of grads are walking away from Big Tech dreams for new career paths

Experts Stress the Industrial Scale of Data Center Water Use

The scale of water use is massive, as the Texas Water Development Board projections estimate that data centers in the state will consume 49 billion gallons of water in 2025, soaring to nearly 400 billion gallons by 2030, as per Techie + Gamers report. That’s about 7% of Texas’s total projected water use, according to the report.

Margaret Cook, a water policy analyst at the Houston Advanced Research Center pointed out that, “These centers are showing up in places that are very water-stressed," adding, "There’s no requirement for them to have conversations with communities about how much water they’ll use,” as quoted in the report.

Locals in the Hill Country region, where several new AI-focused centers are under construction, are raising alarms. Much of the water these centers use evaporates during cooling and can’t be recycled, a critical issue in an area already grappling with scarce water resources, as reported by Techie + Gamers.

ALSO READ: Giant Wyoming data center to guzzle 5x more power than residents, but the user remains secret

Microsoft’s Sustainability Promise Faces Skepticism

While Microsoft said it’s working toward sustainability goals, aiming to be “water positive” by 2030, meaning it plans to replenish more water than it consumes, as per the report. The company highlights water restoration projects and the use of recycled water when possible, according to Techie + Gamers.

However, critics worry these efforts often happen far from the communities facing water shortages, limiting their impact.

Cook said, “You have to question what ‘water positive’ means when you’re building massive projects in places already dealing with water scarcity,” as quoted in the report.

Transparency is another problem. Some water utilities learn about new data centers only after construction is underway, and companies sometimes operate under shell entities or code names, reducing community awareness and input, as reported by Techie + Gamers.

This issue isn’t just about the future, it’s happening now, with drought conditions already severe across many parts of Texas, the expansion of AI infrastructure is testing how communities balance technological progress with environmental sustainability, as per Techie + Gamers.

ALSO READ: As the July jobs report paints a grim picture, 114 companies plan layoffs in August - is yours on the list?

FAQs

Why are Texas AI data centers using so much water?
They use water mainly to cool the servers that run around the clock, which is essential to keep the data centers operating safely.

Can the water used by data centers be recycled?
Some water is recycled, but a large portion evaporates during cooling and is lost forever.

Much of the water these centers use evaporates during cooling and can’t be recycled, a critical issue in an area already grappling with scarce water resources, as reported by Techie + Gamers.ALSO READ: Giant Wyoming data center to guzzle 5x more power than residents, but the user remains secretMicrosoft’s Sustainability Promise Faces SkepticismWhile Microsoft said it’s working toward sustainability goals, aiming to be “water positive” by 2030, meaning it plans to replenish more water than it consumes, as per the report. The company highlights water restoration projects and the use of recycled water when possible, according to Techie + Gamers. However, critics worry these efforts often happen far from the communities facing water shortages, limiting their impact. Cook said, “You have to question what ‘water positive’ means when you’re building massive projects in places already dealing with water scarcity,” as quoted in the report.Transparency is another problem. Some water utilities learn about new data centers only after construction is underway, and companies sometimes operate under shell entities or code names, reducing community awareness and input, as reported by Techie + Gamers.This issue isn’t just about the future, it’s happening now, with drought conditions already severe across many parts of Texas, the expansion of AI infrastructure is testing how communities balance technological progress with environmental sustainability, as per Techie + Gamers.ALSO READ: As the July jobs report paints a grim picture, 114 companies plan layoffs in August - is yours on the list?FAQsWhy are Texas AI data centers using so much water?They use water mainly to cool the servers that run around the clock, which is essential to keep the data centers operating safely.Can the water used by data centers be recycled?Some water is recycled, but a large portion evaporates during cooling and is lost forever.
